title: The 'messy' path to start-up success (with Kass & Mike Lazerow from SXSW) | Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: hey folks Jeff Burman here I got the
chance to talk to my very old and very
dear friends Cass and Mike lazro on
stage at South by Southwest earlier this
month and we wanted to share that
conversation with you Cass and Mike are
two of the very smartest very best
entrepreneurs investors and humans I
know and I've had the pleasure of
watching them work working with them for
a very long time now now I was on their
board at buddy media the SAS company
that they built from scratch from the
ground up and eventually sold to
Salesforce for nearly a billion dollars
and now Cass is on the board of wait
what the company that makes this podcast
so we're keeping this all very much in
the family this week Cass and Mike are
unabashedly honest about how hard it is
to build successful companies especially
when your co-founder is also your spouse
house this is masters of
scale the lazaros have distilled their
most valuable lessons into a new book
which is coming out this spring it's
called
shoveling yes
shoveling a love story about the
entrepreneur's messy path to success we
talked about this love story live on
stage in Austin Texas as part of South
by Southwest and I started by asking C
pass about the messiest parts of their
careers their toughest business moment
was back just before the.com Bubble
Burst Mike and Cass were Newly Weds and
they were co-founders of the site and
the business
golf.com we had sold golf.com to
chipshot and chipshot worked in uh
Silicon Valley and they made custom golf
clubs in the most expensive part of the
world we were bought in uh December 23rd
1999 and we were psyched this company
was going public in the spring we were
like our board had all voted for it we
were like oh my God this is the Heyday
of everything that you wanted for the
internet like this was ET toys was going
public for like billions of dollars and
on in March I think it was March 3rd
2000 we got a call that said hey I just
wanted to let you know this is from the
president of chipshot so the deal hadn't
formally closed you you signed an
agreement to sell the company a Chip
Shot going public it was closed it was
fully closed fully closed we no longer
had control of our bank accounts okay
every bit of money was coming from
chipshot March 3rd 2000 I pick up the
phone it's the president of Chip Shot
saying I'm very sorry I have bad news
we're going out of business and I said
what the you know what the we doing here
and we we we can it's Texas we can we
can first okay so I said what the
are you talking about and basically he
said that uh seoa who had backed them to
go public had pulled out and there was
no more filing and they were going
bankrupt and we would they'd be out of
business in two weeks and they had no
more money to pay anything for us
nothing for payroll nothing zero and and
this was not a deal where you had taken
a whole bunch of cash off the table they
had this this was a all stock deal we
were psyched we thought we had hit it
and and your your team members were
going to do
as big time and we own more than 50% of
the company so so set the stage for us
you're now in in March this call comes
in Where Are You When the Call Comes in
so we actually lived above our office
and when we got too big we started
bringing people up into our living room
and we were in what was the bedroom so
the three founders Mike myself and Mike
Casper were in the back and just for the
record there was only one bathroom so
anytime someone had to go to the
bathroom they had to walk past us which
is incredibly embarrassing it was the
poop deck yeah the poop basically the
poop deck and um there's going to be a
scatological theme to all of this where
yeah and so we were sitting there in the
bedroom part of this office and I put it
on speaker and then Mike and cper came
by and they're like we just started
firing questions and I actually think
there was an employee in the bathroom at
the time that came out and was like is
everything okay and the answer is no no
immediately yeah so so you're you're in
the bedroom you're taking this call it
is a deluge of bad news the is
hitting the fan um you must have been
personally devastated yes I think the
first thing that came to my mind was all
the employees right I didn't even go to
the all the investors and we had a lot
of friends and family in the in in as
investors but I immediately went to oh
my God how am I going to hey these
people this is their livelihood what's
going to happen so what happens next you
you you hang up this call are you
calling lawyers are you are you trying
to figure out how to how to back out of
the like what do you do well the first
thing is is I had to calm down I was
angry so I felt an immense amount of
responsibility to everybody there I felt
like I was duped right so of course I'm
the operator so I'm a COO so I'm going
back like I'm going backwards I'm like
okay what what did I miss and do Ence
what did they say to me I'm looking
through notes I keep looking at Mike's
like okay okay and then I like what are
we going to do and he's he literally
turned to me and he's like we're going
to start this again we're going to just
start it again we're going to do this
and so Mike where did that come from I
mean I think most people be spinning
yeah so it came from just this idea
we've always had which we didn't know at
the time which was you just keep going
as an entrepreneur so as an entrepreneur
you show up to work and hits the
fan this particular day it rained
right it was like
whoa and what we have to realize is
1999 the frenzy around the internet was
like Taylor Swift meets
AI like globally everyone's talking
about the internet e toys is doing like
100 million of sales but it's worth like
$50 billion and you know everything's
going up and to the right and we sold to
a sequoia back company and we were in
our heads very rich you we owned half of
this company and on paper on paper and
so all of a sudden it's like oh we have
like no money now um which was fine so
we didn't really have money at the time
and I remember sitting down what do we
need to do and the first thing we need
to do is raise money and so we hit the
road with our partner went to San
Francisco go the bay area which was very
expensive hotels so we stayed at a motel
that had you know the thick glass like
bulletproof at the but there were three
of us in one room we shared a room with
our co-founder which is like little
awkward um you know cuz we uh had just
gotten married we got married October
23rd
1999 we did what no one probably should
do which is start a company while you're
dating um but to us I was 25 I'm like
you know she she's really smart she's
hot she's like loves the internet I'm
all
in
and you objectively you hit the lottery
yeah and I'm like cross eyes like bad
heart I'm like okay I was like are you
alive and like me that's all I needed um
we got lucky like a lot of this is luck
and we met a guy named Keith Bank in
Chicago and we raised I think 1.2
million or 1.5 million in one lunch wow
yeah and that was like such a key
meeting and we filled it in with a few
others our former investors in golf.com
some of which were friends and
family just weren't pleased with us um
that I think that's a bit of an
understatement corre yeah yeah what was
the worst part of that the worst part I
would say is that well first of all I
think telling our individual families
that we lost their money and don't
forget that you have startup costs when
you start a company and that comes from
yourself right unless you can take a
loan or anything um but I think the
worst part was that a very close family
member sued us and just demanded the
money back and over and over again I had
calls then I got lawyers to tell them
like this is not going to happen this is
not I mean I don't have any money to
give you it's not even legal and then he
basically threatened to kill Mike which
was pretty be awful um I'm like why
me it was a little odd that he didn't
threaten to kill me not your family like
direct family it was a little bit odd
but um at the time I think I was just
deeply embarrassed by that like thinking
to myself like how does this happen it
was a good lesson in pick your investors
wisely yeah okay and make sure that they
can afford to lose whatever they're
putting in so you raised This 1.2
million
over lunch with a bunch of golf dudes at
a legendary Country Club and what what
happens from there we went back I think
the first thing that would that made
like brought a little bit of Joy was
that I could hold an all team meeting
and say we're back in business so that
is like a feeling of just massive relief
so we did that and we put our heads down
and you have to understand this is now
2000 there is nothing nothing living
right no compies are living the 1.0
bubble
has no one cared about us there there
wasn't a lot of business we we had to
like limp along we were mostly dead
right but barely alive for seven years
until the ad Revenue business started
coming back and you were able to sell
the company ultimately it's also a story
another story of luck which is there is
this you know young kid who does not
look like most golfers so there's a
black kid who dominates the Masters and
and at the time Tiger Woods like tiger
was as big of a name as Taylor Swift
right like everywhere in the world tiger
tiger tiger every company and we
basically rode Tiger Woods and Phil
mikkelson that rivalry to a $25 million
sale to Tai Warner which was a company
that used to exist um there was a big
company media and cable and all of
that's now broken up and disintegrated
and crash and burned a lot of it um but
we were the kind of online piece of Golf
Magazine and Sports Illustrated which
they owned and that got us to New York
which then opened up a whole world of
New York Tech Innovation which we've
been in since we moved in 2005 2006 so
before we get to the next phase of the
entrepreneurial journey I want to go
back um uh they not a ton of uh part who
are dating who start a company together
then get married and and go forward um
your your journey together didn't
actually start with dating no take me
back okay you had to go there I we have
to go there so I basically grew up in
his house so I am a few step out for a
few
minutes I am a few years older than he
is he will love to to say it's just a
fact right that's what you're going to
say and
um so I was uh best friends with his
older brother and that was the house to
hang out in when we were younger and I'm
talking like high school years and we
should probably disclose at this point
that I was also hanging out in that
house so he is one of my best friend
since I was
16 and it's pretty awesome to be sitting
up here I just want to say that and we
would always so Andrew his brother and I
would have to bribe Mike to get out of
the basement so that we could all hang
out and I would take any dollarss that I
had from allowance or anything and we'd
pull money to get him out cuz he was
such a pain in the ass he was a great
entrepreneur from very early on he had a
business being a professional pain in
the ass yes and so that is the
background and I grew up in his house um
never dated Andrew I just want to make
sure I'm totally clear on that didn't
date Mike's brother no and never even
looked at him I looked at him as a pain
in the ass little brother and then we
met up in '96 at our mut ual friends
wedding Kevin Kane and Jill and we got
paired and by the way thanks for bailing
that night I bailed you bailed that
Friday Night of the rehearsal dinner of
Thanksgiving weekend very tough weekend
to have it I was told everyone was going
and I did what my mother told me you
RSVP you show up so I showed up and it
was Andrew Mike and me as the only
representatives of our our friend group
and so Andrew said you and Mike need to
do a toast to represent I'm like oh my
God God I have to do it Mike he talks so
much and um he such a big talker we all
avoided you you know that right we all
the girls avoided him because you've
been talking a lot more of this podcast
than I
have I'm just
like and so basically we got up there
and we did this toast and it was magic
yeah we filled in each other's sentences
everyone afterwards was like how long
have you been dating Mike starts making
stories he basically closed the deal
that night that we were dating on the
spot like we'd been dating for 20 years
and that was that and then that was
history and and here we are now so okay
so that that that just sets the stage
for for for where we're going um Mike
you you founded your first company in
college what what tell us about the
start of your formal entrepreneural
Journey there yes so you know I came
from a relatively entrepreneurial family
small businesses you know small money
manager small developer parents were
divorced so I had kind of Two Dads um
very different but not like a Rich Dad
Poor Dad way but just very different and
I went to Northwestern to journalism
school and it was pretty obvious even
freshman year in
1992 that the internet was coming really
93 it's super early but if you think
about some of the early sites like
Craigslist and you know even the you
know eBay it was like oh classified ads
which kind of support
newspapers and I just went down a rabbit
hole with the internet and I had an idea
for a business which was instead of
running kind of AP news stories in
college papers I was involved with a
daily Northwestern let's create our own
student wire and so I built a network of
700 campus papers they contributed their
content and exchange they got all the
other content I owned the rights to the
content I could Syndicate it which
became very valuable as ESPN and other
sites grew because all of a sudden I had
the Michigan dailies football content
right which I could Syndicate and then I
had a press release service where if you
wanted to reach 700 campus newspaper
editors you could just blast it out so
it was a business that was doing okay
and then I merged it with a marketing
company called student Advantage which
we took public um actually
before we did golf.com and it was a
company that went from you know zero to
100 million in sales on the back of an
AT&T calling card so they would give
away our product the student Vantage
card calling cards don't exist and which
is why the company doesn't exist I me
newspapers don't exist newspapers don't
really exist and I just knew the
internet when I go down a rabbit hole I
don't come out until I find something
and so it happened in web 1.0 2.0 it's
happening now with AI and so um when I
met Cass and she was in the internet
business I was like done like at the
time I started there were only 13
million people on the internet I hadn't
really met other people who were
interested in Internet businesses being
in Chicago not the Bay Area and that's
how it got started so I mean there there
are very few people who start one
company and exit it and do a second
company and have some success and not
withstanding the the Chip Shot crazy um
you did have a successful exit uh so
that's that's two um you know at that
point you're married you've got uh uh I
think two kids with one on the way right
if I but when we start the next company
that's right right and and and and you
would be understood for saying well I'm
going to hang out at timing for a little
while I'm going to take some time off
I'm gonna I'm going to figure it out but
you didn't you started yet another
company why well it usually happens
around the birth of every kid and and he
he loves to think um like you said in
rabbit holes and so uh May 24th 2007
Facebook announced that you that it was
opening up its platform and you could
develop on it and so I get pulled out
from you know just delivering uh our
daughter our third child and and uh
we're in the recovery room and Mike goes
I've got it so just just be clear yes
you've just given birth to your third
child yes it's not C it's not 3 weeks
later you're sitting on the couch you're
in the recovery room and it was I I was
in a lot of pain and he goes I've got it
and I literally think he is getting me
sushi like this is going to be he's
going to get me pizza and he's going to
get me sushi and this is going to be
great and I go okay where are you going
to order from and he goes no no no no I
know what we're going to do next I said
are you kidding me and he goes
no this is it this is it you have no
idea what's about to happen I know the
next company and we're doing it so M
what what happened in that moment where
did that where did that come from and
what what was the thing I knew about
Facebook about 200 million people on it
I was kind of fascinated and Mark
Zuckerberg gets on stage says we're
opening up our platform we're exposing
the social graph anyone who wants to can
build apps on Faceook Facebook and this
is back before Facebook had kind of
impacted democracy and mental health and
all this stuff so it was like kind of a
good thing for the world we thought it
was a simpler time it was a simpler time
and I just thought that like
everything's better with friends but
when Facebook recreated the social graph
that kind of the real life map of
relationships and you could put that on
apps it fundamentally changed the
internet and we ended up
launching a business that became buddy
media we didn't know it was going to be
a software company it had to Pivot a few
times would have never called it buddy
media if we thought it would be a
software company so you you you you
talked about the company pivoting a few
times what was the initial Vision once
you got past kind of the the space you
knew you want to go into where did it
start and where did it this is pretty
ugly though yeah so the initial Vision
was we want to bridge the commercial
world like businesses advertising with
Facebook
and it took us I think four business
models to get there we pivot really fast
we love throwing away stuff and so the
first idea was probably the worst idea
I've ever come up with in the history of
ideas I remember going into HBO at the
time I said we can help you on Facebook
we got this thing called Ace bucks and
they just like laughed but they said can
you help us deploy our content on
Facebook and we heard that in enough
time so he said okay we're going to
Pivot into software to help the largest
brands in the world which I think is a
really important moment in the story
because you're out pitching one thing
the Market's giving you feedback on the
product that the market needs and so
rather than searching for product Market
fit you're actually being told by the
customers what product Market fit looks
like and you have to be ready to listen
to that because half the time with
pivots it's ego right that you don't do
the pivot so you have Founders who sit
there and go well wait I raised money on
the first idea um I can't go back to the
board and tell them that this isn't
working I can't go back to my family and
tell me that this isn't working so you
have to listen and we were having clear
feedback to us around the time that Cass
and Mike were getting buddy media up and
running I was working at Myspace and
shortly after I left Myspace I went out
to New York and part to see them and we
sat in their makeshift conference room
room and they showed me what they had
built so far at buddy
media and we started riffing on what it
could be where it could go what the
market needed what the business
opportunities were and before I knew it
they were offering me a seat on their
board I said we got to get him on the
board because at that point we were
moving so quickly that I think I needed
someone that I could bounce ideas off of
and that was another lesson that I
learned that you need to have a working
board you need to have people who
actually help you right so they have to
have a purpose it's not just like oh
they gave you money and they get a seat
at the board it's like no what are you
going to do for that money Mike there's
something very powerful about how you
communicate with boards and and how you
manage boards and this is one example
that I've learned so much from you about
how you do this can you can you talk
about your philosophy on that how you
did it at buddy and how you now advise
companies to do it yeah so I think the
biggest issue with Founders and their
relationship with words
is they don't the founders don't have a
clear Comm a clear idea of what is going
on right they can't they can talk about
it but they really can't think clearly
about their plan and so I would write
these epic letters which would take
probably like a day where I'd outline my
thinking here's what we said we would do
here's what we're doing here's where
we're going here's
why and that forced me to put it down in
paper and if it didn't make sense to me
it would never make sense to anyone else
and so board decks are very useless
other than the financials because it
doesn't really tell a story if you can't
sit there and
communicate what you're doing why you're
doing what are the top three areas of
focus why those areas of focus are so
important you will never be able to move
the board forward let alone your team
I've always treated the board as
partners not as bosses I'm no better
than them or you know worse it's just we
are Partners in this and it has helped
and it's helped me as you now that we
have like a hundred investments in the
tech space I think it's helped me work
with entrepreneurs better because I
really asked them to Rite it down like
if it's not written down it doesn't
exist I think Mike's also not telling
the other story so at golf.com when we
started like we had to redo the whole
company that meant new money right and a
new board and we had two sharks on our
board now we didn't own much of the
company and that was Jeremy Mage and
Matt sovich and they had a hedge fund
and I remember the first board meeting
that I gave right so whole new company
and he said how do sales going I'm like
yeah you know sales is going pretty good
I mean Mike why don't you talk about it
and Mike says yeah you know it's going
and that he interrupts and Matt sovich
I'll never forget it screams at the top
of his lungs at me don't shine the
turd and I remember just kind of like
literally like losing the blood in my
face having Goosebumps and going okay
and that was the lesson and so Mike took
that so what did what did you hear when
he said don't shine the turd say the
sale what the sales are they're not good
they're not great they're not okay say
the number say what's going on be
truthful be transparent like have
radical
transparency and it doesn't matter if
it's your board your employees you've
got to be transparent and I think Mike
did took that lesson cuz we were like it
was as if we had just been massively
reprimanded and we took that lesson and
he did such a good job going forward and
that was it it was just full
transparency going forward I think we
realize that people
in general are are okay with bad news
especially these days right um but even
then like they're fine with bad news
people hate surprises so if they think
things are going this way but they're
actually going this way that just like
ruins trust forever it's one thing as
co-founders to figure out roles you're
also wife and husband here um H how do
you to divide roles in in leading a
company so I do everything that's
operational so anything that touches
legal accounting teams employees HR
Finance um and then I also took on
marketing which is unusual but it's like
a Pastime for me and Mike is always
doing Vision sales strategy board
raising money I got all the credit like
earns and young entrepreneur of the Year
all these things Cass does all the work
and she made me look
incredibly great and these companies
only work if they're operated incredibly
well it's not the ideas you have to have
like a big market and like
differentiated product all that stuff
but how Cass has run companies our whole
life has been the biggest blessing to us
business wise Cass among the things that
you do incredibly well in operating a
company is the team part and you talk
about putting the cult and culture um uh
how do you do that how do you do that
great how'd you do that at buddy media
so I think it stems from my childhood I
don't want to be like over dramatizing
this but I did not have the team
atmosphere in my childhood that I had
wanted I'm the fourth kid there were a
lot of Alliance games I always felt like
I was not getting picked on a team if
that relates to anybody and um
ostracized at some points and that was
just such a awful wound that I thought
literally in everything I did I remember
I kind of was in a sor when I say kind
of like I didn't participate but then I
decided okay if I'm going to participate
I'm going to take a role and going to
try to make the culture better so the
same thing happened at all all of the
companies I did I wanted to create an
atmosphere where there were no alliances
where there was none of this um
clicks and literally there were times
where I saw like mean girl stuff
happening not just with girls and I
literally brought them in and I said if
I see it again you're fired on the spot
period pencil down we're not going to
have that we're going to lift everybody
up and then you have to think about the
tools right how do you what's the glue
to connect everybody everyone talks
about oh how it's so hard right now
because everyone's remote it is but you
have to think about how do people Bond
they bond in bad times and they bond in
Good Times so if you're transparent
that's incredible if you celebrate the
small wins together that's a pretty
obvious one so I wanted to start the

scavenger hunts I made everyone dress up
I had leadership team who did not want
to do it and I basically said I'll fire
you there are a few companies in the
category that are swirling but he's the

there's a process that leads to selling

Salesforce was really talking to us

globally we have offices in Singapore
and this we're like can't keep up right
and we just told the story the way we

her credit
she took the
job and I I kept thinking I don't know

had to have another scary conversation

Microsoft was looking to acquire in the

work um you guys had a choice right you
you could keep going it alone and
probably go public and and try to stay
on the trajectory or or sell and and you
you ran a really interesting process
tell us about the process you ran and
why you ultimately sold a Salesforce so
we ultimately sold
because the signs were so clear that it
was our time to sell we had I I've never
told this story publicly but we had a
term sheet from Google that was a $100
million more than
Salesforce 100 million is a lot of money
it's a lot of money and and it was a lot
of money for us that difference and we
had Yahoo and Microsoft
circling and I had been in San Francisco
and I went to Mark's house and I had all
the data and I used this mapping tool
where I just like circled an area of the
map and it put all the people on
Facebook into a targeting bucket and
Mark is like me in the sense said like
you can't we can't control our like
excitement like when I get excited you
know it's like I kind of jump out of my
shoes and Mark's like oh like this is so
cool and we basically hashed out the
deal and I had I knew nothing about the
software business but Mark had written a
book that's like here's our
